keyTakeAways: China has expanded its export controls on rare-earth metals, adding five new metals (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, ytterbium) to its existing list, bringing total restrictions to 12 out of 17 rare-earth elements.

The restrictions apply to both raw metals and specialized equipment used in refining rare-earth metals, with foreign companies needing special approvals for exports involving products with at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth metals.
China cites national security and threats from foreign entities using or transferring Chinese rare-earth materials for military applications as justification for the controls.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth minerals and products, having imported $22.8 million in 2023, with 70% of its imports coming from China between 2020 and 2023.
Rare-earth metals are vital for US defence systems such as F-35 jets, submarines, missiles, radar, and AI semiconductors, making the controls strategically significant.
The move is seen as a form of 'pre-meeting choreography' to strengthen China’s negotiating leverage during the upcoming Trump-Xi meeting at the APEC summit in South Korea.

The restrictions are part of a broader strategic competition in critical minerals and supply chains, with China leveraging its dominance (60% mining, 90% processing) to influence global trade dynamics.
China has exempted exports related to emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, and disaster relief from the restrictions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has announced expanded export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five new additions—holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium—effective from December 1, 2025. These controls apply to both raw metals and specialized refining equipment, requiring foreign companies to obtain special approvals detailing the intended use of the products. China justified the measures as a national security response to foreign entities using or transferring Chinese rare-earth materials for military purposes. The move occurs just weeks before a high-stakes diplomatic meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping during the APEC summit in South Korea, positioning China's actions as a strategic signal to strengthen its leverage in ongoing trade negotiations. The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, with 70% of its rare-earth imports coming from China, and the restrictions directly impact critical defence technologies like fighter jets, submarines, missiles, and AI semiconductors. Analysts from CSIS and the University of Montana interpret the controls as a calculated 'pre-meeting choreography' designed to pressure the US and widen the strategic gap in critical mineral supply chains. Exemptions are granted for emergency medical and disaster relief purposes.
